It's the biggest leash-yanker in this game.

I'd say this game is trying to make a commentary on triple-A FPS's like Call of Duty and Battlefield, by saying if their gameplay was the same as Manhunter, they'd be considered just as bad because of their poor stories. Developed by the Polish Studio 'Silden', Manhunter (or Sniper: The Manhunter) is a run 'n gun FPS game that I feel is misplaced on the PC platform. If this were something that I played on a tablet, I feel it would be a passable game! With the limited power of Ipads (or god forbid, a Blackberry Playbook) I might even go so far as to say the game looks pretty decent and is an overall good package... BUT I'm not reviewing a tablet FPS game, this is a PC FPS game and whats here is an extremely repetitive, poorly optimized, uninspired mess of a game.

- Presentation: Graphically, I've seen worse. If you look at the screenshots you might catch yourself thinking it doesn't look half bad. That is because you haven't seen the game in motion. I admit, my 3 year old PC is far from a beast but I can still run Battlefield 4 on High at 50fps, meanwhile the FAR LESS graphically intensive Manhunter here struggles to stay at a consistent 30fps and has enough head bobbing to simutaniously give me a headache and motion sickness.

- Animations: There is barely any. When switching weapons blink in and out and all making the same noise as the reload sound. Enemies/NPCs don't even have walking animations, everybody just jogs everywhere in the same fashion and sometimes in sync. reviewText: Back in the day....there was a company called 'Groove Games'....that put out loads of budget titles for $20 or less. Most of them were poorly made....but they still had a certain charm to them....kind of like all of the killer shark movies that the 'SyFy' channel has begun to crank out on a yearly basis. The games were very basic....but they worked....which is more than Manhunter" can claim. When you start the first mission....there is some spoken dialogue that is supposed to give you some insight into what you are supposed to be doing....but there is some sh***y Iranian orchestra music blaring which drowns everything else out. You start off in a helicopter and are supposed to be sniping some targets from the air....but good luck with that. But at least you seem to be invulnerable while in the air....'cause I kept getting shot over an over and nothing happened. After a couple of minutes of this bullsh**....the helicopter finally lands and as soon as your feet touch the ground....you will know just how broken the game actually is. First up....the walking. Your character walks like he is riding a pi**ed off bull....and you have to somehow hold on for eight seconds.  More annoying than that.....is the jumping. This game has the exact same gravity as The Moon. You can jump high and float in the air for several seconds. Want to jump rooftop to rooftop? Well guess what....you can. Just keep in mind that if you cross any invisible barriers in your travels....the game will give you a few seconds to get back before it makes you start all over. Which is something that you may have to do often.....since when I followed my A.I. teammate towards a hill.....the game demanded that I stay on track....before ultimately informing me that I failed the mission. The music is terrible and can not be turned off. Sure.....there is an option to do so in the main menu....but it doesn't work. The weapon selection is bewildering to say the least. You start the first mission with a silenced pistol....a sniper rifle....and um.....another sniper rifle. You can pick up AK-47's from enemy soldiers....which kind of made me feel like the Doom Marine for a second....since that was pretty much the last time that I remembered carrying a huge surplus of weapons in a FPS. This game has absolutely nothing going for it....and it's not even good in a bad kind of way."

Where do I begin...

You play as the protagonist, Max. Max is your stereotypical video game soldier with an australian accent. The voice acting is monotone and emotionless. Speaking of characters, in cutscenes the characters waddle like they have been holding a gran caca for several months. The pelvis doesn't even move. As for the gameplay. If you are killed and restart the dialogue starts up before the game loads. Combat is wonky. A pistol is even better than an AK47. Also, for some parts of the game you can sprint, and as you sprint the enemies spawn and won't attack until they run to their scripted spawn. You can literally run straight up to them and knife them. column42:
because when I'd hang behind my cover for just about 7 seconds to heal (which takes forever to do in this game)- a random baddy would either spawn behind me or run around on my side and start shooting me. And I've even seen some enemies hide behind foliage, which I found oddly smart for the otherwise ignorate AI. And all your enemies are either Russians or Middle Easteners, so you already know the game's view on relationships with people outside their own country.

The music is also very limited. There are only two different tracks that play during shoot-outs and that's it. There is no music beyond that. And whenever you finish a shoot-out, the music will cut off awkwardly. And this isn't a glitch (even though this game is filled with those), because during the 5 hours I played this game- this would happen every time I killed the enemies in a room (which would be hilarious if I killed a guy in room, and the music would only pause for two seconds, as I'd open the door and new enemies would come out.)

The levels are very straightforward and pretty easy to grind through to get to where you want to get to. But the game is a bit too linear. If you deviate even a little from the course (or want to try swimming) you have 4 seconds to retrace your steps or you are screwed. And the save points in this game suck, because of how poorly dispersed they are. I don't like manual saving because it makes a game easier, I like manual saving because it makes a game less repetitive- something that Manhunter wouldn't hurt to not have. It's INCREDIBLY frustrating when you step out for two seconds, accidentally get blown to smithereens by the enemies, then get teleported to fifteen minutes earlier in the game. It's the biggest leash-yanker in this game.

I'd say this game is trying to make a commentary on triple-A FPS's like Call of Duty and Battlefield, by saying if their gameplay was the same as Manhunter, they'd be considered just as bad because of their poor stories. But, I think that's a bit too deep for anyone to get out of a game like this. Manhunter is a definite must-not-play. If you just bought this game and looked at my review, take my advice and refund it that very second! It is one of the worst games on Steam!
